title: Broken Arm
summary: Guide for providing first aid to someone with a suspected broken arm, including immobilization techniques and pain management.

steps.title: Assess the Injury
steps.description: Check for signs of a fracture: severe pain, swelling, deformity, inability to move the arm, or bone protruding through skin. Do not move the arm unnecessarily. Call 911 if bone is visible or circulation is compromised.

steps.title: Immobilize the Arm
steps.description: Support the injured arm in the position found. Do not try to straighten it. Use a sling made from a triangular bandage or improvised from clothing. Support the arm against the body.

steps.title: Apply a Splint if Trained
steps.description: If trained, apply a splint using rigid material (cardboard, magazines, boards) padded with soft material. Secure with bandages above and below the fracture site, but not directly over it.

steps.title: Manage Pain and Swelling
steps.description: Apply ice wrapped in a cloth to reduce swelling - never directly on skin. Give over-the-counter pain medication if conscious and able to swallow. Keep the arm elevated if possible.

steps.title: Monitor and Transport
steps.description: Check fingers for circulation (color, warmth, sensation) every 15 minutes. Remove rings or jewelry before swelling increases. Transport to emergency care or wait for ambulance.

warnings: Never try to realign or straighten a broken bone
Do not give food or drink if surgery may be needed
Watch for signs of shock: pale skin, rapid pulse, shallow breathing
whenToSeekHelp: Call 911 immediately if bone is visible through skin
Seek emergency care for all suspected fractures
Call 911 if person shows signs of shock or has multiple injuries
preventionTips: Use proper safety equipment during sports and activities
Maintain good bone health with calcium and vitamin D
Remove fall hazards from home environment
